intro: Paepalanthus wurdackii, commonly known as the Andean buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Andes Mountains. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family and is characterized by its yellow flowers and hairy, glandular leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to the cool, temperate climates of its native habitat. It is often found in open areas such as grasslands and slopes, where it thrives in full sun. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
